description:
A basic laboratory course in which both the theoretical and practical aspects of a variety of organic reactions and multistep syntheses are emphasized. Modern chromatographic, instrumental, and spectroscopic techniques are applied to experimental organic chemistry. Course should be taken concurrently with CHEM 242 or in the semester immediately following. For safety reasons students will not be permitted to wear contact lenses in the laboratory. 

PLEASE NOTE THE FOLLOWING: For the Summer and LPS offering of CHEM 245, it is a 2-semester course. Part 1 is taken in the first term for 0.0 CU and then Part 2 is taken in the second term immediately following the first for 1.0 CU.
name: EXPERIMTL ORGAN CHEM I

values.comments:
Part 1 of a basic laboratory course in which both the theoretical and practical
aspects of a variety of organic reactions and multistep syntheses are emphasized. Modern
chromatographic, instrumental, and spectroscopic techniques are applied to experimental
organic chemistry.
Students seemed to really enjoy the class even though they felt it was quite
challenging and time consuming. Many appreciated the “applications of theoretical
organic chemistry” during lab time. A number of students felt the class was “valuable” in
that it taught basic laboratory procedure and provided more insight about the reactions
covered Chemistry 242.
Professor Mallory received stellar reviews from her students. Students described
her as “friendly and helpful” as well as a “warm presence” in lab. Many appreciated how
thorough she was in explaining reactions and procedures. The only complaint from
students was that Professor Mallory was unwilling to provide hints in regards to what
exams would cover.
The class is primarily composed of biology and chemistry majors as well as prehealth
students. The class does require a great deal of work. One student mentioned it
demanded “30 hours” of work per week. Grading for the class is quite stringent as only
30% are allowed an A. In addition to lab time, students should expect to put in a
significant amount of work both preparing for labs and writing post-lab reports.
